title-group.article-title: Experimental investigation of the impact of post-injection on emissions, combustion and lubricant dilution in a diesel engine with B20 fuel

contrib-group.aff: EMS Energy Institute, Pennsylvania State University, USA

author-notes.corresp: André L Boehman, EMS Energy Institute, John and Willie Leone Family Department of Energy and Mineral Engineering, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, 16803, USA. Email: boehman@ems.psu.edu

abstract.p: A 100 hour (h) engine experiment was conducted to investigate the impact of post-injection strategy on emissions, combustion and lubricant dilution with a common-rail turbocharged direct-injection diesel engine at moderate speed and low load. The fuel was a B20 v/v blend of a soybean methyl ester-based biodiesel and ultra low sulfur diesel. The impacts of post-injection on engine performance and emissions were investigated. The total acid number of the lubricant, the engine mechanical friction mean effective pressure and hydrocarbon components in both the exhaust gases and the used lubricant were analyzed. The variations of engine performance strongly depended on the timing of the post-injection. The key parameter that controlled the combustion process of post-injected fuel at late crank angle (later than 40° after top dead center) was found to be the cylinder temperature at which the post-injected fuel was about to ignite. The bulk cylinder temperature threshold was confirmed to be 1500 K, below which a rapid combustion of injected fuel was not observed. The vaporized components of the post-injected fuel were found to contribute the majority of the significantly increased unburned hydrocarbon emissions with the post-injection strategy. Furthermore, these unburned hydrocarbons were also found to be the primary source for lubricant dilution.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The diesel engine is widely used in heavy-duty transportation, but its applications are strongly affected by increasingly strict emission regulations. Research on engine emissions improvement includes consideration of fuel composition, exhaust aftertreatment and engine control strategies. Biodiesel, as a sustainable fuel produced from animal fats and vegetable oils,1,2 is a very attractive alternative to diesel fuel since it has been widely observed to decrease particulate matter (PM), CO and unburned hydrocarbons (UHCs).3–8 The absence of sulfur in most biodiesel fuels can also increase the durability of nitrogen oxide (NOx) storage and reduction catalysts.9,10 At the same time, engine emission reduction with multi-injection strategies has been a widely adopted technique.11–15 Specifically, multi-injection strategies with post-injection, which is fuel injection considerably after top dead center (ATDC), have been reported to improve the NOx–PM trade-off by many researchers.16–20 Furthermore, the higher exhaust temperature from post-injection can also be used to re-generate aftertreatment devices,21,22 such as diesel particulate filters and NOx adsorber catalysts.

Although drawbacks, which include an increase of NOx emissions3–8 and an increase of CO and UHC emissions,16–20 have been observed for both biodiesel and post-injection, respectively, the combination of biodiesel and post-injection may provide synergistic effects. However, so far, only a limited amount of relevant work has been reported, and a few potential issues may also arise. For example, unexpected lubricant dilution may be introduced23 since the emissions of UHCs, which may be dissolved into the oil film on the cylinder wall, are significantly increased by post-injection.7,16–20,24 In addition, the complexity of the lubricant dilution may increase as a multitude of hydrocarbon species from the exhaust can be observed in an engine using post-injection with diesel fuel.21 This issue of lubricant dilution will become more severe when biodiesel fueling is used, since biodiesel tends to concentrate in the lubricant25,26 due to its higher boiling point22 than diesel fuel. A high level of lubricant dilution has a negative impact on engine performance since it can increase mechanical friction,23 engine wear,27 and metal corrosion,28 which can pose additional challenges for lubricant development. However, a systematic understanding of these issues is not available due to the lack of published studies combining both biodiesel and post-injection strategies.

Overall, the impact of post-injection on engine performance and oil dilution with biodiesel fueling is still not well understood. The work presented here investigates the impact of post-injection on exhaust emissions, fuel combustion and lubricant dilution with one 100 h engine test using B20. In addition, the hydrocarbon species in both exhaust and used lubricant were characterized.

sec.title: Technical approach
sec.p: One 100 h engine test was performed with an eight-cylinder 6.4 l Ford ‘Powerstroke’ direct-injection diesel engine. The engine was equipped with two variable geometry turbochargers and a common-rail fuel injection system (180 MPa maximum injection pressure, maximum of five injections within one combustion cycle). The injection strategy was controlled through an electronic interface. The engine had a maximum brake power of 261 kW at 3000 r/min, and a peak torque of 881 N.m at 2000 r/min. The compression ratio was 17.2. The original engine calibration complied with Environment Protection Agency (EPA) Tier 2 Bin 9 emission standards.

During the 100 h test period, the engine was operated at a moderate speed and low load condition: 1500 r/min and 270 N.m torque (30% of maximum torque). The moderate speed was selected to approximate the highway driving condition, and a low load was selected to limit fuel consumption. Exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) level was maintained at around 10% during the test, and the intake manifold pressure was controlled at around 1.5 bar. The fresh lubricant was obtained from Infineum USA L.P. The test fuel was a B20 blend (v/v%) of soybean methyl ester (SME)-based biodiesel obtained from PeterCremer, L.P., and ultra low sulfur diesel (ULSD) obtained from Valero Energy Co. Figure 1 shows the fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) composition of B100 measured by gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS). The B100 used in the experiment primarily consisted of methyl linoleate (C18:2), methyl oleate (C18:1) and methyl palmitate (C16:0). The FAME composition information of biodiesel in the 100 h used lubricant is shown in Figure 1, and will be discussed in a later section.

caption.p: Fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) composition of fresh B100 and of the biodiesel in used lubricant. The error bars were generated as the standard deviation of three analyses of each sample.

sec.p: The engine operation was divided into multiple time blocks ranging in duration from 3 to 8 h. The engine was filled with fresh lubricant at the beginning of the test. At the end of each test interval, a 50 ml oil sample was taken for analysis. Table 1 shows the variation of engine control settings during the test on post-injection. The introduction of post-injection brought the total number of injections to three, and the injection quantities and timings of the pilot and main injections were controlled by the engine’s default calibration. With the addition of post-injection, the injection timing of the main injection event tended to be retarded and the injection quantity of the main injection event tended to decrease since a portion of the work was done by the combustion of post-injected fuel. The timings of post-injection ranged from 45° to 70° ATDC to cover the zone at which both late combustion and lubricant dilution were observed. The quantity of post-injected fuel was controlled precisely by the engine’s electronic interface. Engine status (e.g. exhaust temperature and brake specific fuel consumption (BSFC)) were recorded every 2 h, and the data were averaged within each test interval.

caption.p: Engine conditions during the test. ATDC: after top dead center; mf: mass flow of injection; SOI: start of injection.

sec.p: Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was used to measure the biodiesel dilution level of lubricant oil samples. The authors artificially mixed 3%, 5%, 8% and 10% v/v diluted lubricant standards with B100 and measured their infrared absorbance. A linear correlation between the absorbance of the peak at 1746 cm−1 and dilution level was observed, as shown in Figure 2. Equation (1) was regressed from the correlation and used to calculate the oil dilution level

The total acid number (TAN) of the oil sample was measured according to American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) standard method D974. In addition, the used lubricant after the 100 h test was distilled at 432 °C (which was the highest boiling point of the biodiesel that was used, determined using a simulated distillation method). The lighter cut was collected and analyzed using GC–MS. Hydrocarbons from the engine exhaust were collected in chilled dichloromethane and also analyzed using GC–MS. A detailed description of the collection method can be found in Zhang et al.29

caption.p: Correlation between absorbance of peak 1746 cm−1 from Fourier transform (FTIR) spectroscopy and dilution level.

sec.p: Pressure traces were measured using an AVL GU12P pressure transducer, which replaced the glow plug in the engine cylinder. The voltages from the pressure transducers were amplified by a set of Kistler type 5010 dual mode amplifiers. The amplified voltages were read by a National Instrument data acquisition (DAQ) system. Heat-release data were calculated after the acquisition of the pressure trace, following the zero-dimensional thermodynamic model suggested by Heywood.30 The value of γ, which is the ratio of constant pressure heat capacity over constant volume heat capacity, was estimated using a polynomial function of temperature.30 Mechanical friction mean effective pressure (mfMEP) during the engine operation was calculated using equation (2), which was based on the suggestion by Heywood,30
where IMEPg is the gross indicated mean effective pressure, which was calculated from pressure–volume data, BMEP is brake mean effective pressure and PMEP is the pumping loss.

The engine was not equipped with an aftertreatment device. The exhaust gases from the engine went through a heated filter and a heated sample line, both held at 190 °C. The NOx concentration of the exhaust gases was measured using an AVL CEB-II emissions bench. For each condition, the engine was operated for 15 min to stabilize. Data were recorded every 15 s for a period of 20 min. The measurements were performed three times for each condition to assess repeatability and experimental uncertainty.

sec.title: Exhaust emissions
sec.p: Figure 3 shows the impact of post-injection strategy on NOx, CO and UHC emissions. NOx emissions were decreased by around 50% when the post-injection was introduced. Compared with the introduction of post-injection, changes of NOx emissions from varying post-injection timing, however, were insignificant in this experiment. Reasons that may contribute to the NOx reduction when post-injection was added include a retarding of the main start of injection (SOI), as shown in Table 1, and a decrease in the peak heat release,31 which will be discussed in a later section.

caption.p: Brake specific emissions of engine test with various post-injection settings. The error bars were generated as the standard deviation of emission benches. CAD: crank angle degree.

sec.p: Both UHC and CO emissions had similar tendencies with the variation of post-injection. An increase was observed for both UHC and CO emissions when the post-injection was introduced, which was consistent with other research.7,16–20,24 When retarding the timing of post-injection from 45° to 60° ATDC, both UHC and CO emissions significantly increased. The highest emissions of both UHC and CO were observed with the post-injection at 60° ATDC and 8 mg/stroke (stk). When comparing with the same injection quantity (5 mg/stk), retarding the post-injection timing from 60° to 70° ATDC increased UHC emissions, but decreased CO emissions, which suggested that fewer hydrocarbons from the post-injection were oxidized.

sec.title: Exhaust temperature and BSFC
sec.p: Exhaust temperature and BSFC are sensitive indicators of engine performance. Figure 4 illustrates the exhaust temperatures and BSFC during the 100 h test. When there was no post-injection during the 75 to 100 h period, both the exhaust temperature and BSFC were the lowest. The highest exhaust temperature was observed when the post-injection was set at 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk). The BSFC also increased when the post-injection was set at 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk), which was consistent with the increased exhaust temperature and UHC emissions (Figure 3).

caption.p: Exhaust temperature and brake specific fuel consumption (BSFC) profile of the 100 h test. Each point is the average of one test period. The dashed lines are used to divide zones of each post-injection strategy. The error bars were generated as the standard deviation of measurements within one test time block. CAD: crank angle degree.

sec.p: While retarding the post-injection from 45° to 60° ATDC without changing the injection quantity, the exhaust temperature decreased, but the BSFC still increased, which suggested that more fuel escaped the cylinder. This observation was also consistent with the trend of UHC emissions (Figure 3). Increasing the post-injection quantity to 8 mg/stk slightly increased the exhaust temperature, but significantly increased the BSFC, suggesting that more fuel escaped the cylinder.

Setting the post-injection quantity back to 5 mg/stk, but retarding the injection timing to 70° ATDC, decreased both the exhaust temperature and BSFC. Compared with the 60° ATDC (5 mg/stk), the exhaust temperature was lower but the BSFC was significantly higher. These trends were also consistent with UHC emissions. This showed that retarding post-injection timing decreased the combustion efficiency of the post-injected fuel, which had a significant effect on UHC emissions.

One can estimate the increase in BSFC due to biodiesel energy content versus post-injection. Given that ULSD has a low heating value of 42.7 MJ/kg, while B20 has a low heating value of 41.6 MJ/kg, and no significant change in engine thermal efficiency, as shown by many researchers,6,32–38 B20 fueling is expected to increase the BSFC by 2.5%. With the introduction of post-injection, based on Figure 4, it can be easily calculated that the increase of BSFC is (a) 8% at the post-injection of 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk), (b) 14% at the post-injection of 60° ATDC (5 mg/stk), (c) 24% at the post-injection of 60° ATDC (8 mg/stk) and (d) 18% at the post-injection of 70° ATDC (5 mg/stk). This increase of BSFC by post-injection is significantly higher than B20 fueling.

sec.title: Heat-release analysis
sec.p: Heat-release analysis is critical in the understanding of engine behavior. Figure 5 illustrates the pressure traces of tests with different post-injection strategies at around TDC and late crank angle (LCA) (i.e. later than 40° ATDC). It is obvious that the peak pressure for no post-injection was the highest, and the peak pressure for 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk) post-injection was the lowest. This decrease in peak pressure with post-injection is consistent with the fact that a portion of work was done at LCA by the combustion of post-injected fuels, and tests with 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk) post-injection generated the most LCA work. This is also confirmed by the pressure traces at LCA (Figure 5), because tests with post-injection had higher pressures in the later stage of the combustion cycle. Thus, to maintain a constant power, the engine decreased the work from the pilot and main fuel injections. As shown in Table 1, retarded SOI and decreased fuel injection quantity of the main injection event were observed. The pressure traces for 60° ATDC (5 mg/stk), 60° ATDC (8 mg/stk) and 70° ATDC (5 mg/stk) were similar, which suggests similar post-combustion conditions. They had lower peak pressures than for no post-injection due to a retarded and smaller main injection event, which is due to the energy provided during oxidation of post-injected fuels. However, the peak pressures were higher than the case of 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk) and the pressures at LCA were lower than the case of 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk), which suggests a weakened post-combustion.

caption.p: Pressure traces of test with different post-injection strategies at (a) top dead center (TDC) and (b) late crank angle (LCA). CAD: crank angle degree.

sec.p: Apparent heat-release rate and cumulative apparent heat release are shown in Figure 6. The combustion of fuel from the pilot and main injections for each test can be observed. For the post-injected fuel, however, the apparent heat-release rate only can be observed in tests with post-injection at 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk). This combustion, which consumed most of the post-injected fuel, explains the increase of exhaust temperature and pressures at LCA. The slight increases of BSFC and UHC emissions suggest that this combustion at LCA was not as complete as that occurring around TDC. The lack of complete combustion at LCA in the other post-injection tests also explains their significant increase of UHC emissions and BSFC.

caption.p: (a) Apparent heat-release rate and (b) cumulative apparent heat release with different post-injection strategies. CAD: crank angle degree.

sec.p: In addition, from Figure 6, it is apparent that the cumulative apparent heat release for the post-injection cases increased at LCA, which suggested that the post-injected fuel still reacts and generates thermal energy. This also confirms that not all post-injected fuel had been consumed by the combustion events at LCA. The case of 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk) had the lowest cumulative apparent heat release from the main combustion event (around TDC) since there was a portion of energy provided via post-combustion. In contrast, the cumulative apparent heat release of the main combustion events for the case of 60° ATDC (5 mg/stk), 60° ATDC (8 mg/stk) and 70° ATDC (5 mg/stk) contributed to the majority of the total energy, which also indicates that in these cases, post-combustion was not as strong as for the case of 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk). Nevertheless, a slight increase in the cumulative apparent heat release can be observed, suggesting continuous fuel oxidation. It is worth mentioning that the total cumulative apparent heat release for all cases, regardless of existence or timings of post-injection event, was consistent given the engine was operated at a stable condition.

Thus, retarding post-injection timing significantly decreases the combustion efficiency at LCA. Furthermore, these results suggest that between 45° and 60° ATDC, there was a post-injection timing threshold that determined whether combustion at LCA can consume the post-injected fuel. Figure 7 illustrates the computed bulk cylinder temperature. Apparently, the 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk) case had significant temperature increases at LCA due to the combustion event. Although the tests with 60° ATDC post-injection timing did not show a similar temperature increase as that with 45° ATDC post-injection, they still had slight increases in temperature at LCA compared with no post-injection. The temperature increase for 70° ATDC (5 mg/stk) post-injection was the least significant of the post-injection cases. Hence, the bulk cylinder temperatures suggest that the post-injected fuel from different injection timings went through different combustion paths: that the 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk) had high-temperature combustion and that 60° ATDC (5 mg/stk), 60° ATDC (8 mg/stk) and 70° ATDC (5 mg/stk) only followed low-temperature combustion mechanisms.29,39,40

caption.p: Bulk cylinder temperature of tests with different post-injection strategies. The arrow points to the lowest acceptable combustion temperature. CAD: crank angle degree.

sec.p: Cylinder temperature is the most critical parameter that determines the path of combustion at LCA.41 The fuel injected into the cylinder experiences an atomization–combustion process, and the time between SOI and start of combustion (SOC) is defined as the ignition delay. Here, a predictive model (equation (3)) suggested by Assanis et al.42 was employed to predict the ignition delay of the post-injected fuel in the combustion chamber of the diesel engine

where τID is the ignition delay in ms, ϕ is the overall equivalence ratio, and

sec.p: For post-injection at 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk), the injection timing was 405°, and the ignition delay was 0.64 ms, which is 5.7° for an engine operating at 1500 r/min. This timing was consistent with its SOC at LCA (Figure 6). Furthermore, it also represents the timing associated with a critical temperature of 1500 K. According to Sjoberg and Dec,44 1500 K is the lowest bulk cylinder temperature at which high-temperature combustion can happen before the combustion is quenched by piston expansion. As explained by Sjoberg and Dec,44 OH content, which is required for the dominant CO oxidation reaction (Reaction I, which produces 78% of total CO244), becomes too low to initiate the reaction below 1500 K

For post-injection at 60° ATDC, the injection timing was 420°. The ignition delay was 1.61 ms (14.5°) for the injection quantity of 5 mg/stk, and 1.40 ms (12.6°) for the injection quantity of 8 mg/stk. These timings were consistent with the start of the temperature rise in Figure 7. In addition, the bulk cylinder temperatures at the start of the temperature rise were only around 1300 K, which explains the significant change in the combustion behavior when the post-injection was retarded to 60° ATDC. For post-injection at 70° ATDC (5 mg/stk), the injection timing was 430°. The ignition delay was 2.67 ms, or 24.0°. The cylinder temperature when the fuel was ignited was about 1150 K. This further decreased the rate of oxidation of the post-injected fuel.

Table 3 presents the calculated results of hydrocarbons consumed from the post-injected fuel, assuming the UHCs from the pilot main injection were negligible, based on the injection quantities and emission measurements. The combustion for 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk) post-injected fuel consumed the most hydrocarbons, while the combustion for 70° ATDC (5 mg/stk) post-injected fuel consumed the least, which was consistent with the measured UHC emissions. The rates of fuel consumption by the combustion of post-injected fuel in both tests with post-injection at 60° ATDC were similar due to their similar temperature environments, which suggests that at the same post-injection timing of 60° ATDC, the injection quantity did not significantly affect the amount of fuel consumed by the post-combustion.

caption.p: Calculated unburned hydrocarbon (UHC) emission rate and consumed hydrocarbons by combustion at LAC. B20 is a fuel mixture blended with 20% v/v soybean methyl ester (SME)-based B100 and 80% v/v ultra low sulfur diesel (ULSD). Engine runs at speed of 1500 r/min. ATDC: after top dead center.

tr.th: Consumption by combustion of post-injected fuel (g/min)

sec.title: Lubricant oil dilution level, TAN and mfMEP
sec.p: Figure 8 illustrates the profiles of TAN, lubricant oil dilution level and mfMEP during the 100 h test. It shows that no lubricant oil dilution was observed when the post-injection was at 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk). Retarding the post-injection timing to 60° ATDC immediately increased lubricant oil dilution level. However, the subsequent changes of post-injection timings and quantities did not have a significant impact on the rate of dilution; that is, the slope of increase of dilution level appeared to be stable. When the post-injection was disabled, the dilution stopped increasing. The slight decrease observed at the beginning of the final 25 h operation without post-injection (immediately after 75 h) may have been due to the fuel vaporization from the lubricant. Using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation,45 based on the suggested normal boiling point from Yuan et al.46 and enthalpy of biodiesel from Goodrum,47 one can estimate the boiling point of biodiesel to be around 550 °C at 20 bar, around 500 °C at 10 bar, and around 470 °C at 7.5 bar. Therefore, it is possible that the small quantity of post-injected fuel quickly vaporized since its boiling point was much lower than the local temperature, which may suggest that the mechanism of biodiesel dilution is the dissolution of gas-phase hydrocarbons into the lubricant film on the cylinder wall. Based on the above hypothesis, given the similar cylinder pressure and cylinder wall temperature in the various tests, the hydrocarbon concentration in the liquid would be similar, regardless of the hydrocarbon concentration in the gases, if it was simplified as a binary system (light unburned hydrocarbon and heavy oil) and the oil film was saturated.48 This may explain the observation that the change of in-cylinder hydrocarbon concentration did not significantly affect the quantity of fuel diluted into the oil, as shown in Figure 8 that the change of post-injection strategy did not have a significant impact on the rate of dilution. At the same time, Fisher et al.49 observed that the liquid fuel penetration length of biodiesel from a 108 µm diameter injection gave a comparable value to the cylinder radius of a common light-duty diesel engine, which may suggest that fuel impingement on the cylinder wall could also contribute to oil dilution. Unfortunately, the orifice diameter of the engine in this work is not available during the present work, and more detailed investigations will be conducted in the future to reach explicit conclusions on the dilution mechanism.

caption.p: Total acid number (TAN), dilution level and calculated mechanical friction mean effective pressure (mfMEP) profiles of the 100 h test. The error bars were generated as the standard deviation of three measurements of each sample. CAD: crank angle degree.

sec.p: The TAN showed an initial decrease and remained stable until around 30 h. It then increased slightly and stayed at a constant level until around 60 h. After that, the TAN kept increasing until the end of the test. This was consistent with the effect of the acid control additives in the lubricant since they were designed to have a 60 h control of lubricant acidity, as indicated by the company providing the lubricant oil. After the effect of acid control additives, the oxidation and degradation of lubricant oil generally showed an increase in TAN in most normal operations.50–52 At 0 to 30 h, the mfMEP showed an initial increase, then a decrease, which was attributed to a break-in process,53 given this was a relatively new engine at the time of the present work. After 30 h, there was no distinct trend. Nevertheless, a weak correlation between the mfMEP and oil dilution level can be observed, which may suggest an increase of friction due to the decrease of oil viscosity53 from dilution.

sec.title: Analysis of hydrocarbons from the lubricant and exhaust
sec.p: Figure 9 illustrates the GC–MS analyses of the diesel base fuel, B100, and the lighter cut from a 432 °C distillation of fresh and used lubricant. The region of interest in the mass spectrum includes hydrocarbons that do not originate from the lubricant. The results for the used lubricant evidently show a portion of the paraffins from the base diesel fuel and the FAME components from biodiesel. This confirms that both diesel and biodiesel were diluted into the lubricant. Other hydrocarbons in the used lubricant have not been detected from the GC–MS analysis, which suggests that fuel rather than combustion by-products was the primary source of lubricant dilution.

caption.p: (a) Gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) results of diesel, B100, lighter cut from 432 °C distillation of fresh and used lubricant. (b) Region of interest in the GC–MS results. The numbers at the diesel zone means the number of carbon in the relevant paraffin.

sec.p: Figure 10 shows the GC–MS analysis of hydrocarbons collected from the exhaust for the tests with different post-injection strategies. Consistent with the UHC emission results, the exhaust hydrocarbons in the case without post-injection and the case of 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk) were hardly detectable, but significant in the other three cases. The majority of hydrocarbon components were paraffins that evaporated from the diesel fuel, FAMEs from biodiesel and smaller molecular by-products from combustion. These by-products, such as benzene and toluene, however, had too low boiling points to be diluted into the lubricant. Further smaller molecules were not detected by the approach used. This also confirms the absence of high-temperature combustion for the cases of 60° ATDC (5 mg/stk), 60° ATDC (8 mg/stk) and 70° ATDC (5 mg/stk).

caption.p: Gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) results of hydrocarbons collected from exhaust gases for various post-injection strategies. CAD: crank angle degree.

sec.p: Additionally, only paraffins with carbon numbers larger than 14 were able to be diluted into the lubricant. This suggests an average operating temperature of the oil film at around 400 °C according to the boiling point of C14H30 at 10 bar.46 Smaller molecules may tend to vaporize at this temperature rather than condensing and dissolving into the lubricant.

Compared with fresh B100 fuel, as shown in Figure 1, the FAME composition of the biodiesel diluted in the used lubricant had a significant decrease in the most unsaturated hydrocarbon methyl linoleate, but showed various increases in the other FAME components, the highest of which was methyl stearate. This can be explained by the higher oxidation instability of unsaturated FAME compounds and the lower boiling point of methyl palmitate.

Overall, use of a post-injection strategy can be an effective approach to reduce NOx emissions and initiate regeneration of aftertreatment devices. However, it will increase the fuel consumption as well as CO and unburned hydrocarbon emissions. Hence, post-injection is not an efficient strategy for in-cylinder NOx emissions control. Nevertheless, post-injection has demonstrated effectiveness for regeneration of aftertreatment devices. The combustion behavior and lubricant oil dilution significantly depended on the post-injection strategy, including the SOI and quantity of post-injected fuel. With biodiesel fueling, no significant oil dilution can be observed if the post-injection timing is earlier than 45° ATDC for the condition tested here.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A multiple-injection strategy including post-injection is an effective way to decrease NOx emissions and increase exhaust temperature for diesel engines. Depending on the timing and quantity of post-injection, the engine showed a significant change in exhaust temperature, BSFC, UHC and CO emissions. Between the post-injection timings from 45° to 70° ATDC, the consumption of post-injected fuel was found to primarily depend on the injection timing.

Post-injection at 45° ATDC with the quantity of 5 mg/stk underwent significant combustion at LCA, i.e. later than 40° ATDC. Compared with other more retarded post-injection timings, it generated significant power – reducing the energy requirement for the pilot and main injections – and produced a higher exhaust temperature with only a moderate increase in BSFC. The increases of UHC and CO emissions compared with the test without post-injection are also less severe than other post-injection timing cases.

Post-injection at 60° ATDC (5 mg/stk), 60° ATDC (8 mg/stk) and 70° ATDC (5 mg/stk) did not have significantly apparent heat release at LCA. Compared with 45° ATDC (5 mg/stk), they generated much less energy, decreased the exhaust temperature and significantly increased BSFC, UHC and CO emissions. Nevertheless, oxidation of post-injected fuel can be still observed at LCA.

A model was employed to calculate the ignition delay of the post-injected fuel. The temperature at which the ignition was supposed to happen was confirmed to coordinate with the quality of combustion of post-injected fuel at LCA. A bulk cylinder temperature of 1500 K was confirmed to be the lowest acceptable temperature for which high-temperature combustion of the post-injected fuel could occur in the engine before the flame was quenched by the piston movement.

When the fuel was injected into an environment with a temperature lower than 1500 K, only slow fuel oxidation occurred. Hence, the fuel escaped the cylinder at a much higher rate than under high-temperature combustion conditions. GC–MS analysis showed that the primary hydrocarbons in the exhausted gases were vaporized diesel and biodiesel components, regardless of the post-injection strategy, and those hydrocarbons became the primary source for lubricant dilution when they were mixed into the oil film on the cylinder wall. Additionally, in this experiment, only paraffins with a carbon number larger than 14 from the diesel fuel and FAME from the biodiesel were observed to dilute into the lubricant because of the high temperature of the cylinder wall.

The authors wish to express their gratitude to Dr Joseph Perez and the Tribology Group in the Department of Chemical Engineering of the Pennsylvania State University for help with FTIR analysis. The authors also wish to express their gratitude to Dania Alvarez Fonseca of the Analytical Research Group at the EMS Energy Institute of the Pennsylvania State University for help with GC analysis.
